data.title: How to Dial Abroad Without Making Mistakes: International Phone Number Format & Examples
data.meta_description: Tired and frustrated of mistakenly dialing international phone number? Hop in and we will teach you how to dial abroad without making mistakes and things to avoid.
data.text:
In our phone-connected world, communication barriers have nearly been eradicated, and borders are increasingly blurred by various means. That being the case, International phone numbers are the true medium, making cross-border communication possible.

Whether you need to connect with loved ones overseas or conduct business with international partners, making phone calls properly is crucial. And to do it correctly, at all times, you need to master the art of international dialing with precise knowledge of all international phone number formats.

But where to get that expertise? Well, that‚Äôs what this blog is all about.

In this blog, we aim to provide you an overview of the international phone number format and its components, make you familiar with the writing format of some major countries, and finally, provide a list of do‚Äôs, don‚Äôt & tricks to remember.

So, first, let us introduce you to International Number Formats.

What is the International Phone Number Format?

The international phone number format is a standardized way of writing a telephone number, and it is a globally recognized numbering plan for international telephone numbers. It is also known as the E.164 standard, which was established by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) to ensure consistent and reliable worldwide communication. Having learned that, now, let‚Äôs move on to the technical bits.

What are the Components of International Phone Numbers?

In general, a typical international phone number consists of three main components. And to make it even simpler for you to get associated with all those elements, here is a breakdown of those:

Country Code: It is a unique prefix assigned to each country, usually ranging from one to three digits in length, which is used to identify the country to which a phone number belongs to.

Area Code/NDC/Dialing Code: It is a three-digit number that is assigned to a specific geographic region within a country, which is used to distinguish between local and long-distance and then to route calls to the correct area. For example, 888 is the area code related to the toll-free number in North America.

Subscriber Number(SN): It is the remaining set of digits representing the unique phone number of a specific subscriber or telephone within a country. Its length varies from country to country and is of the following types-

Mobile Numbers: These numbers are designed to be used on mobile phones and typically have a specific format that includes a Mobile Country Code (MCC), a Mobile Network Code (MNC), and then the subscriber‚Äôs number, making them usable across the designated country.

Telephone Numbers: These numbers are directly assigned to landline phones and are used to make and receive calls within a specific geographic area. Their format varies depending on the country and are commonly known as Local numbers.

Toll-Free Numbers: Toll-free numbers are special phone numbers that can be dialed for free from any phone in a country and are typically used by businesses and organizations. Toll-free numbers typically have a specific format that starts with a specific prefix, such as ‚Äú800‚Äù in the United States.

All these three components are joined to make a complete international number, which all together constitutes a maximum of 15 digits and is formatted as follows: [Country Code] + [National Destination Code] + [Subscriber‚Äôs Number].

Here are some real-life examples of international phone numbers from different countries and regions.

How to Write US Phone Number in International Format?

In the United States, phone numbers are typically written in the format: (XXX) XXX-XXXX. To write a US phone number in international format, you would add the country code before the local number.

The international format for a US phone number would be +1 (XXX) XXX-XXXX. Below is a table that depicts various US phone number types:

How to Write UK Phone Number in International Format?

There is a standard way of writing phone numbers in the UK by using XXX-XXX-XXXX. You would need to add the country code to a UK phone number in order to convert it into an international format.

The international format for a UK phone number would be +44 XXX-XXX-XXXX. Below is a table that depicts various UK number types:

How to Write Canadian Phone Number in International Format?

In Canada, phone numbers are typically written in the format: (XXX) XXX-XXXX. To write a Canadian phone number in an international format, you would first have to add the country‚Äôs code before the local number. +1 (XXX) XXX-XXXX is the international format for a Canadian phone number.

The following table illustrates various types of Canadian numbers:

How to Write Australian Phone Number in International Format?

The format of Australian phone numbers is XXX-XXX-XXX. If you want to write an Australian phone number in the international format, you must add the country code before the local number, which would be like this: +61 XXX-XXX-XXX.

Below is a table that depicts various Australian number types:

How to Write Indian Phone Number in International Format?

In India, phone numbers are typically written in the format XXX-XXX-XXXX. To write an Indian phone number in international format, you would add the country code before the local number. Then the international format for an Indian phone number looks like this: +91 XXX-XXX-XXXX.

Here is a table that shows the various Indian number types:

How to Write French Phone Number in International Format?

X-XX-XX-XX-XX-XX is the typical format for French phone numbers. When writing a French phone number in an international format, you should enter the country‚Äôs code first and then the local number. A French international phone number would be like this: +33 X-XX-XX-XX-XX.

Here is a table that contains all the number types used in France:

How to Write German Phone Number in International Format?

German phone numbers are typically written in the format XXX-XXX-XXXX, and to write those in the international format, you have to add the country code before the local number. To make the identification process easier, here is the usual German phone number format: +49 XXX-XXX-XXXX (for international calling).

Japanese phone numbers are typically written as XX-XXXX-XXXX. To write a Japanese phone number in international format, you would add the country code, which would look like this: +81 XX-XXXX-XXXX.

How to Write Philippine Phone Number in International Format?

Phone numbers In the Philippines are typically written in the format XXX-XXX-XXXX. The international format for a Philippine phone number is +63 XXX-XXX-XXXX. Here is a table that displays the number types used in the Philippines:

How to Write Brazilian Phone Number in International Format?

In Brazil, phone numbers are typically written in the format XX-XXXXX-XXX. To write a Brazilian phone number in international format, you would first have to add the country‚Äôs code before the local number, which would look like this: +55 XX-XXXXX-XXX.

How to Write Nigerian Phone Number in International Format?

In Nigeria, phone numbers are commonly written in the format XXX-XXX-XXXX. To convert a Nigeria phone number to an international format, you would add the country code before the local number. Then, the international format for a Nigeria phone number would be +234 XXX-XXX-XXXX. Below is a table that depicts various Nigerian phone number types:

International Phone Number Dialing Etiqques: Do‚Äôs & Don‚Äôt

Having learned what international number formats are and their components, and also having understood how to correctly write those for various countries.

There‚Äôs still a list of guidelines you need to follow while exploring the world of international numbers to eliminate the existence of any errors, like unfamiliar dialing codes and country-specific protocols, that might unintentionally occur. To make things easier, here are some Do‚Äôs, Don‚Äôts, and some tips that you must follow as a traveler or business personnel any & all the time-

Do‚Äôs:

Research Country Codes: Know the country code of the destination you‚Äôre calling. It‚Äôs like the secret handshake to get your call through.

Use the ‚Äò+‚Äô Symbol: Start your number with the ‚Äò+‚Äô symbol, followed by the country code. This magical ‚Äò+‚Äô works across borders, making your call internationally friendly.

Double-Check Numbers: Precision matters. Recheck the number before hitting that dial button to avoid ending up in the wrong hemisphere.

Include Local Area Codes: Some countries require you to dial a city or area code before the local number. Be thorough, and include it.

Understand Time Zones: Nobody likes a 3 AM wake-up call. Be mindful of the time zone differences and call at a reasonable hour.

Consider the Receiver‚Äôs Time: If it‚Äôs a personal call, think about when the other person is likely to be available. Work calls during their lunch break might not be appreciated.

Don‚Äôts:

Assume One Format Fits All: Different countries have different formats for phone numbers. Don‚Äôt assume a universal style‚Äîresearch and adapt.

Forget the Exit Code: If you‚Äôre dialing out from a different country, use the exit code of the country you‚Äôre in before dialing the international number. It‚Äôs the door out.

Ignore Language Differences: If English isn‚Äôt the dominant language, make an effort to learn a few basic phrases or hire an interpreter. It‚Äôs a nice touch.

Rely Solely on Mobiles: While mobiles are convenient, sometimes landlines are the way to go. Check what‚Äôs more suitable for the country you‚Äôre dialing.

Skip on Country-Specific Rules: Some countries have additional digits for special services or require a specific sequence for mobile numbers. Respect the local rules.

Assume Your Phone Works Everywhere: Not all phones are created equal. Check if your phone is compatible with the local network or if you need a SIM card.

Special Tips for Travelers and Business Professionals

Use International Roaming or Local SIM Cards: Firstly, activate international roaming on your phone, and if not possible, consider getting yourself a local SIM card to avoid excessive charges and save some bucks.

Explore Communication Apps: Secondly, try using VoIP communication apps like WhatsApp, Skype, Zoom, or Cloud-telephony services for cost-effective international calls or video conferences over Wi-Fi.

Have Emergency Contacts Handy: When traveling to unexplored territories, make sure you have saved some important local and international emergency contacts in your phone for quick access. It can be the thing that saves your life.

Test Your Connectivity: The last tip that you must follow all the time is to test your connectivity to avoid dropped calls or poor audio quality before even beginning to make a call.

The Wrap-up!

Bringing all the things together, in this blog, we highlighted everything about international phone number format and its components, discussed how to correctly write international phone numbers of some famous and well-known countries, and provided you with some crucial tips, do‚Äôs & don‚Äôts to be always followed in any scenario.

However, it is crucial for you, yourself, as a phone number user to be able to recognize and understand all the varying phone number formats across the world and to accurately write those. As this knowledge can help you get rid of communication barriers, ensure that you can contact the person you want, lead to effective communication, and to avoid confusion and error in both personal and business contexts.

FAQs

How to write my phone number in International format?

To write your phone number in an international format, you‚Äôll need to know the country code for your country. You can find country codes online or in a phone book. Once you have the country code, follow these steps:

To begin, enter the country code, which is a 1 to 3-digit code prefixed by ‚Äú+‚Äù or ‚Äú00‚Äù.

Next, add the local area code.

Finally, enter the rest of your phone number. Make sure that you remove any preceding zeros from your number, and also note that the number of digits varies from country to country.

For example, if your phone number is (123) 456-7890 and you live in the United States, your international phone number would be +11234567890.

Are all phone numbers 10 digits internationally?

No, not all phone numbers are 10 digits internationally. The length of a phone number can vary depending on the country. While the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) has set a maximum length of 15 digits for international phone numbers, this means countries can use shorter numbers.

As an example, in the United States, the length of a phone number is seven digits, while in France, it is eight digits

What is the proper format for a phone number?

The proper format for a phone number varies from country to country and the context in it is to be used. However, there are some general guidelines that you can research on and follow when dialing a phone number in an international format. Here is a general outline of a proper format for a phone number:

International format: A plus sign (+) ‚Äì country code ‚Äì city code ‚Äì local phone number(user‚Äôs number).

Landline format: A 2-digit area code ‚Äì a non-breaking space ‚Äì the rest of the number in 2 chunks of 4 digits or altogether.

Mobile format: The mobile operator code- seven to ten digits for the main phone number.

Vanity format: Any combination of unique characters with separators, such as a space, dash, or period.

What is the country exit code for USA?

The exit code for the United States is 011. When you are calling from the United States to another country, you must dial the exit code followed by the country code and the phone number. For instance, to make a call to a telephone number in the UK, you would have to dial 011+44+12345678.
